(h) Cost. The charges for solid waste disposal at the transfer station shall be as established from time to time by the county commission. (i) Acceptance of recyclables. Recyclable items will be accepted free of charge from entities which use the transfer station for waste disposal according to the following: Recyclable items must be delivered separate from waste. Any entity which deposits recyclables in the transfer station contaminated with waste will be subject to a $100.00 fine. (j) Yard trimmings, limbs and untreated lumber. (1) Yard trimmings, limbs and untreated lumber will be accepted for the established tipping fee provided that they are separated from other types of waste. (2) Any entity which deposits yard trimmings, limbs and untreated lumber combined with waste will be subject to a $100.00 fine. (k) Prohibited items. The following items will not be accepted for disposal at the transfer station: (1) All types of cooling units, including but not limited to refrigerators, freezers and air conditioners. (2) Any items specifically prohibited from disposal at solid waste disposal facilities as provided for in the Rules of Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division, Chapter 391-3-4, solid waste management. (3) Items listed in sections 2, 3 and 4 above, unless delivered in accordance with these sections. Editor's note— It is unclear as to what "sections 2, 3 and 4 above" refers. (l) Dead animals. Dead animals will be accepted in accordance with the county policy on the acceptance of animals at the transfer station for disposal. (Code 1985, § 17-47) Secs. 62-8—62-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 62-36. - Definitions. All words and phrases in this chapter shall have their customary dictionary meanings, except those words specifically defined below: (1) The word "shall" is mandatory and the word "may" is permissive. (2) The phrase "solid waste" shall include every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit, or vegetable matter, liquid or otherwise, that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in, or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit, vegetables; all paper, cardboard, wood, plastic, petroleum, glass, or other synthetic or natural products used for building or road construction or other purposes; all motor vehicle or other machinery parts, including motor vehicle tires; all household refuse, including all paper, plastic, aluminum, tin or other containers; all human waste and fluids and devices used for their storage or collection; dead animals; all chemicals of every type and description; all nuclear wastes or products of every type and description, and every other item generally accepted to be waste, hazardous waste, garbage, refuse, trash, or debris. (3) The word "owner" shall mean the owner who will occupy the property as their primary residence. (Code 1985, § 17-1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 62-37. - Generally. (a) No person shall engage in solid waste handling in a manner which will be conducive to insect and rodent infestation or the harboring and feeding of wild dogs or other animals; impair the air quality; impair the quality of the ground or surface waters; impair the quality of the environment; or likely create other hazards to the public health, safety, or well-being as may be determined by the solid waste management director or his/her designee. (b) Provisions of this article apply to all persons presently engaged in solid waste handling as well as all persons proposing to engage in solid waste handling. (Code 1985, § 17-2) Sec. 62-38. - Exemptions. (a) Provisions of this article shall not apply to any individual disposing of solid wastes originating from his or her own residence onto land or facilities owned by him or her when disposal of such wastes does not thereby adversely affect the public health. This article shall not apply to any individual, corporation, partnership, or cooperative disposing of livestock feeding facility waste from facilities with a total capacity of up to 1,000 cattle or 5,000 swine. If such individual, corporation, partnership, or cooperative shall provide an approved waste disposal system which is capable of properly disposing of the runoff from a ten-year storm, such individual, corporation, partnership or cooperative shall be further exempt regardless of total per head capacity. Nothing in this article shall limit the right of any person to use poultry or other animal manure for fertilizer. (b) Provisions of this article shall not apply to any individual, partnership, corporation or other entity not collecting and disposing of municipal solid waste, commercial solid waste, construction/demolition waste, or industrial waste for a fee, but who are holders of valid solid waste handling permits from the Director of the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources pursuant to Rules of Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division 391-3-4-02 and 391-3-4-06 for disposal or on-site burial. Such disposal shall be governed by state environmental protection regulations and by the requirements of the current county development regulations. (Code 1985, § 17-3) Sec. 62-39. - Enforcement. The county law enforcement agencies and the board of health shall be enforcement officers of this article unless otherwise provided. (Code 1985, § 17-4) Sec. 62-40. - Disposal of construction debris and waste. (a) No individual, partnership, corporation or other entity shall dispose of construction clearing debris, yard trimmings, and/or solid waste as those terms are defined in the Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq., on private property. (b) Penalties for violation. Any individual, person, corporation or other entity who violates this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-15. (Code 1985, § 17-15; Ord. of 5-4-99) Secs. 62-41—62-55. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - FRANCHISES
Sec. 62-56. - Prohibited acts. (a) No individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity shall engage in solid waste handling except in such a manner as to conform to and comply with this chapter and all applicable state and federal legislation, rules, regulation and orders. (b) No individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity shall collect and dispose of municipal solid waste for a fee without obtaining a franchise from the governing authority. (c) No solid waste may be disposed of by any person in an open dump, nor may any person cause, suffer, allow or permit open dumping on his property as defined by the Rules of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, EPD, Chapter 391-3-4-04. (1) A person shall be presumed to have violated this provision if, upon written notification by the county marshal that litter or solid waste has been dumped on that person's property, not otherwise subject to the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 16-7-51—16-7-54, fails to provide the county marshal or his/her designee within 15 days of notification with written assurance that the accumulation of litter or solid waste will be properly disposed of within 30 days from the original date of notification. (2) No person who first informs the county marshal in writing that illegal dumping has occurred on a particular parcel of that person's property shall be deemed to have violated this provision if such person provides written assurance that all accumulated litter or solid waste will be properly disposed of within 45 days of the date of such written notification and subsequently provides proof of such disposal. (d) The owner or occupant of any premises, office, business establishment institution, industry of similar facility shall be responsible for the collection and transportation of all solid waste accumulated at the premises, office, business establishment institution, or similar facility to the county transfer station or any other state approved solid waste disposal facility. (e) No owner or occupant shall allow the accumulation on his or her residential unit or commercial establishment of solid waste where such solid waste creates or may create a health hazard to neighbors or other citizens, or is unsightly, or emits foul or obnoxious odors which constitute either a public or private nuisance. Such conduct shall constitute a violation of this article. Each day the solid waste remains on the premises may constitute a separate violation of this article. (Code 1985, § 17-21; Ord. of 12-20-94(2)) Sec. 62-57. - Granting of franchises. (a) Copies of this article shall be available for public inspection in the offices of the county clerk, and at other locations as designated by the clerk. (b) Nonexclusive franchises for residential or commercial collection and disposal shall be granted upon application to the director of solid waste management or his/her designee provided franchises meet at least the minimum requirements set out in section 62-58. Franchises authorized in collection and disposal of solid waste shall be granted for a period of no more than three calendar years from January 1 to December 31. (c) Franchisees must agree to provide collection services in residential areas and may pick up only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. The board of commissioners reserves the discretionary authority to revoke or rescind any such franchise in the interest of the health, safety, welfare of the citizens of the county. (Code 1985, § 17-22) Sec. 62-58. - Requirements for franchisees. All franchisees must meet the following minimum requirements: (1) Permit: Prior to engaging in solid waste handling in the county, a franchisee must have obtained a solid waste handling permit from the Director of the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources or any successor agency authorized to issue permits pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-8-24. (2) Insurance: At the time of submission of a signed franchise agreement and prior to engaging in solid waste handling in the county, and annually thereafter, each franchisee shall provide to the solid waste department, proof of insurance as follows: a. At least the minimum statutory workers' compensation insurance as required by Georgia law. b. Comprehensive general liability insurance in the amount of $500,000.00. c. Vehicle liability: 1. $500,000.00 limit per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage. 2. Comprehensive covering all owned, non-owned and hired vehicles. 3. All insurance contracts must specify vehicles for "solid waste collection." d. All comprehensive general liability and vehicle liability shall show the board of commissioners as an additional insured and shall provide for 30 days' notice of cancellation to the board of commissioners. (3) Indemnification: The franchisee shall, at its sole cost and expense, fully indemnify, defend and hold harmless the county, its officers, boards, commissions, employees and agents, against any and all claims, suits, actions, liability and judgments from third parties for damages which may be the result of willful, negligent or tortious conduct arising out of the business of collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste, whether or not the action or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this chapter. (4) Financial stability: All franchisees must submit acceptable evidence as required by the county of the franchisee's financial stability and ability to perform the franchise. This may include but is not limited to a franchise applicant submitting to a credit check. (5) Vehicles: a. All vehicles and containers used for collection operations shall comply with the requirements of Rule 391-3-4-06 of Chapter 391-3-4 (Solid Waste Management) of the Rules of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division, and must be compactor-type trucks, covered or enclosed vehicles. All vehicles must be constructed to be substantially leakproof, constructed of durable metal, easily cleanable and designed to prevent litter from escaping during movement of the vehicle. b. Vehicles and containers shall meet all requirements of the Georgia Department of Transportation for highway safety and local ordinances governing weight and size for the streets which must be traveled for pickup. All vehicles shall be subject to unannounced inspection by county officials for compliance with environmental and highway safety standards. c. All vehicles shall have, conspicuously placed in three places on the vehicle, the name and telephone number of the franchisee. The letters must be of sufficient size and contrast so that they are legible from a distance of at least 100 feet. d. Franchisees shall provide an adequate number of vehicles for regular collection services. Nothing in this article shall prohibit franchisees from sharing back-up vehicles with other franchisees provided that such sharing is adequately covered by insurance. e. All vehicles shall have strobe lights which produce a minimum of 60 flashes per minute (FPM) at 1,000,000 candlepower. Strobe lights shall be placed in a sufficient quantity and location which allows visibility from a 360-degree radius of the vehicle. Strobe lights shall be a minimum of 3¾ inches in height with an amber lens color. (6) Reporting requirements: Within 30 days following the close of each calendar quarter ending March 31, June 30, September 30, and December 31 of each year of operation, the franchisee shall submit to the department of solid waste or his/her designee reports of operation showing the following: a. Tonnage figures showing total waste tonnage collected by service type and origin by governmental jurisdiction. b. Tonnage figures showing total recovered materials collected by type, and proof of recycling in the form of manifests, bills of sale, or other records showing adequate proof of movement of the material to a recognized recycling facility. The franchisee shall maintain at its place of business books and records showing the names and addresses of all owners and tenants with whom the franchisee contracted for solid waste handling services, including the street address for the property served. The franchisee shall submit upon reasonable request of the county to a customer audit by the director of solid waste management or financial audit by a certified public accountant or auditor employed by the county. Except for the operating reports described in subsections (6)a. and b. above, the information provided in accordance with this section shall be confidential. The above information shall be compiled for state reporting and compliance purposes by the county. (7) Disposal assurance: As a condition of the franchise and/or franchise renewal, all applicants shall dispose of solid waste only at the transfer station. (Code 1985, § 17-23; Ord. of 5-7-96, § 17-23) Sec. 62-59. - Franchise fees. A franchise fee as determined from time to time by the board of commissioners and listed in the schedule of fees and charges shall be charged to each franchisee. (Code 1985, § 17-24) Sec. 62-60. - Collection services. All franchisees granted a franchise for solid waste collection and removal for any area(s) shall provide a minimum of the following services: (1) The franchisee shall provide at a minimum weekly collection of waste packaged in a sanitary manner. Each franchisee shall set uniform fees for collection; and charges for residential collection and removal services shall be charged to the owners of the real property served, except that by requesting services, any tenant may become jointly bound to pay same. (2) Collection and removal services for disabled persons and senior citizens 65 years old and older as defined in section 62-61 shall be made and billed as directed in that section. (3) Franchisees may bill customers for three months' service in advance of collection, or following monthly collection, at the franchisee's option. The county assumes no responsibility to franchisee for the failure of any customer to keep current solid waste collection payments. Franchisees shall cooperate fully in any legal action taken by the county for failure of any owner or resident to comply with the provisions of this chapter. (4) For all commercial and industrial customers expressing a desire to recycle, the franchisee shall provide recycling services at a cost negotiated between the customer and the franchisee. The franchisee shall collect items for recycling, at least once every week pursuant to a list of guidelines or as otherwise agreed between the customer and the franchisee. a. The board of commissioners reserves the right to change the type and number of recovered items the county will accept. b. For all residential customers expressing a desire to recycle, franchisees shall provide one recycling container per residence to customers and may charge only to recoup its costs for that recycling container. c. Franchisees may dispose of recovered materials at the transfer station only if the solid waste from residents, businesses, commercial enterprises or others providing the recovered materials are also disposed of at that same transfer station. d. No additional fee, over the amount charged for residential curbside collection of waste, shall be charged by the franchisee for residential collections of recovered materials at least every other week. e. Franchisees may credit customers' accounts at their option for collection of recovered materials and yard trimmings. (5) At the time that recovered materials are placed in designated recycling containers for regular collection, they shall become the property of the franchisee collecting waste for that address. During the 24-hour period commencing at 6:00 p.m. on any day preceding any day designated by the franchisee for collection of recovered materials, no person other than an employee or agent of franchisee shall remove recovered material from the designated recycling container which has been properly placed for collection. Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the right of any individual, organization or other entity from donating, selling or otherwise disposing of recovered material, if such disposal does not violate any applicable statute, regulation or ordinance. (6) The county at all times reserves the right to direct and control the time, place and manner of solid waste handling. Nothing in this chapter is intended to abridge the county's right to ownership and control of the waste stream. (Code 1985, § 17-25; Ord. of 12-20-94(2)) Sec. 62-61. - Elderly and disabled citizens. (a) Nothing in this article is intended to prohibit the franchisee from offering discounts to senior citizens or the disabled. (b) Any person who is a full-time resident of a residential dwelling unit as described above and who is disabled to the extent that he or she is incapable of moving his or her refuse shall obtain a physician's certificate as to such disability. Disabled persons shall not be required to place the refuse at the curbside. This subsection shall not apply unless all of the adult persons in a residential unit are disabled and obtain such physician's certificates. Certificates must be mailed to the franchisee with a copy to the director of solid waste. This subsection also applies to temporary disability not to exceed 90 days. Franchisees may make reasonable rules for noncurbside collection for elderly and disabled persons. (c) Franchisees shall provide recycling services to disabled and elderly persons to the same extent such services may be provided under section 62-60. (Code 1985, § 17-26) Sec. 62-62. - Franchise transfers. (a) Approval of transfer—Requirements. If a franchisee sells or transfers its franchise to another, the franchise shall be transferred as well. Approval of the transfer by the solid waste management director shall be granted provided: (1) All documents regarding the transfer are submitted to the solid waste management office for review at least seven days prior to transfer; (2) All outstanding accounts with the county are paid in full at the time of transfer; and (3) The individual, corporation or entity acquiring the franchise is found to be financially stable and the individual, or any partners or shareholders of the corporation or entity have not previously held a franchise and violated this chapter. (b) Denial of transfer—Appeal. If a request for a franchise transfer is denied by the solid waste management director, such denial may be appealed to the board of commissioners within ten days after the written notice of denial. The board of commissioners will review all evidence submitted to them and within 30 days grant, conditionally grant or deny the franchise transfer. (Code 1985, § 17-27) Secs. 62-63—62-85. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LITTER CONTROL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— An ordinance dated March 1, 2005, amended article III, which consisted of §§ 62-86—62-93, to read as herein set out. Former article III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the 1985 Code; and an ordinance dated Sept. 9, 2003.
Sec. 62-86. - Purpose and intent. The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare through the regulation and prevention of litter. The objectives of this article are: (a) Provide for uniform prohibition throughout Coweta County of any and all littering on public or private property; and (b) Prevent the desecration of the beauty and quality of life of the Coweta County and prevent harm to the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare, including the degradation of water and aquatic resources caused by litter. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-87. - Applicability. This article shall apply to all public and private property within Coweta County. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-88. - Compatibility with other regulations. This article is not intended to interfere with, abrogate, or annual any other ordinance, rule or regulation, statute, or other provision of law. The requirements of this article should be considered minimum requirements, and where any provision of this article imposes restrictions different from those imposed by any other ordinance, rule or regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provisions are more restrictive or impose higher protective standards for human health or the environment shall be considered to take precedence. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-89. - Severability. If the provisions of any article, section, subsection, paragraph, subdivision or clause of this article shall be judged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such order of judgment shall not affect or invalidate the remainder of any article, section, subsection, paragraph, subdivision or clause of this article. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-90. - Definitions. Litter means any organic or inorganic waste material, rubbish, refuse, garbage, trash, hulls, peelings, debris, grass, weeds, ashes, sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, metal, plastic, and glass containers, broken glass, dead animals or intentionally or unintentionally discarded materials of every kind and description which are not "waste" as such term is defined in O.C.G.A., § 16-7-51, paragraph 6. Public or private property means the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; timberlands or forests; and residential, commercial, industrial, or farm properties. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-91. - Prohibition against littering public or private property or waters. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump, deposit, throw or leave or to cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of litter on any public or private property in this Coweta County or any waters in Coweta County unless: (a) The property is designated by the state or by any of its agencies or political subdivisions for the disposal of such litter, and such person is authorized by the proper public authority to use such property; (b) The litter is placed into a receptacle or container installed on such property; or (c) The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, or has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-92. - Flagrant littering (a) No persons, corporations or other legal entity that owns rents or leases residential property in Coweta County may dump deposit discard abandoned furniture or household trash and debris on or near the right of way of any street without removing same for more than seven calendar days. (b) Any person, corporation, or legal entity found to be in violation of this ordinance may be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00. (c) Upon a conviction for violation of this code section the court may impose an order of restitution in an amount equal to the actual cost to the county of clearing county rights-of-way. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-93. - Vehicle loads causing litter. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, in person or by his or her agent, employee, or servant, to use any vehicle to haul any kind of dirt, rubbish, waste, articles or things or substance, whether liquid or solid, unless such vehicle is covered to prevent any part of its load from spilling or dropping at all times while such vehicle is in motion on any street or alley in the county. (b) The requirements of this section for covering such vehicles shall not apply to vehicles carrying brush cuttings, tree trimmings, branches, logs and similar waste material if such matter is securely lashed to such vehicle to prevent spilling or dropping of the aforesaid. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-94. - Violations. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this article. Any person who has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this article, shall be given a notice of violation. A notice of violation of this article shall be made by serving a citation by mail or in person by an officer, agent or official of the county empowered by this Code or by O.C.G.A. to issue citations on behalf of the county. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-95. - Prima facie evidence. (a) Whenever litter is thrown, placed, deposited, dropped or dumped or cast from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane, or other conveyance containing more than one person, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance shall be have violated this article. (b) Whenever any litter which is thrown, deposited, dropped, dumped, cast or accumulated on public or private property in violation of this article is discovered to contain items which display the name of a person thereon in such a way as to indicate that the item belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated this article. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-96. - Penalties. Any person who violates this article shall be guilty of a violation and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as follows: (a) By a fine of not less than $200.00 and not more than $1,200.00; and (b) In addition to the fine set out in subsection 62-96(a) above, the violator shall reimburse Coweta County for the reasonable cost of removing the litter when the litter is or is ordered removed by Coweta County; and (c) (1) In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of-way for a distance not to exceed one mile any litter he has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of execution of sentence; or (2) In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove any and all litter from any public property, private right-of-way, or with prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that he has deposited litter. Pick up and removal shall include any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence; and (3) The court may publish the names of persons convicted of violating this article. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-97. - Abatement. Whenever any person convicted of violating this article shall continue to maintain property in violation of this article, an appropriate designee of the board of commissioners may be empowered to enter upon the property and correct the unlawful condition, and to place a lien against the property for the cost of such litter removal and the cost of preparing and filing the lien, including legal expenses incurred. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-98. - Enforcement. All law enforcement agencies, officers and officials of this state or any political subdivision thereof, or any enforcement agency, officer or any official of any commission of this state or any political subdivision thereof, are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this article. (Ord. of 3-1-05) Sec. 62-99. - Citizen roadside trash program. The county shall provide trash bags and trash disposal at no cost for individuals or groups wishing to pick up trash on county roadways. (a) Any individual wishing to pick-up trash on the county roadways may obtain specially designated bags for such trash pick-up from the environmental management department at no cost. b. A maximum of six bags per person may be issued at any one time to a single person, and a maximum number of 12 bags per year per individual may be issued. Upon approval of the environmental management director, additional bags may be issued for groups wishing to pick up a large area of the roadway or to individuals demonstrating a need for bags in excess of the annual limit. (c) Bags must be left along the roadway where the trash was picked up to be collected by the county for disposal. Bags will not be accepted at county compactor sites or the county transfer station. (d) Once bags are filled, the person or group who obtained the bags shall immediately call the environmental management department for pick up. The county shall pick up the filled bags within two working days of the notification. (e) Bags shall be used only for roadside trash pick-up and for no other purpose. It shall be a violation of this section to place materials other than the trash and debris collected from the roadway for which the bag was obtained, such as household garbage, in a roadside trash bag. Violators shall be prosecuted in accordance with section 1-15 and those individuals found guilty of improperly using the trash bags shall be barred from participating in the program. (Ord. No. 003-08, § I, 2-19-08)

div.head: Chapter 66 - SUBDIVISIONS[1]
div.p: Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— An ordinance adopted April 17, 2007, repealed the Subdivision Regulations of the County. See Appendix A, Zoning and Development. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; planning, ch. 50; utilities, ch. 78; zoning, app. A.

div.head: Chapter 68 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 68-1. - Certificates required. No person shall operate or permit a taxicab or any other automobile owned or controlled by him to be operated as a vehicle for hire in Coweta County without having first obtained a certificate from the county authorizing such operation. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-2. - Place of business required. Where the business is located in the county, no taxicab or any other automobile for hire shall operate in the county unless the owner thereof shall maintain a place of business from a building located on property within a commercially zoned district in which vehicles for hire is a permitted use in accordance with the most recently adopted zoning map and have first obtained certification of compliance from the county planning department. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-3. - Operation of vehicles for hire. No person shall operate a taxicab or any other vehicle for hire unless such person possesses the proper driver's license as required under the laws of the state and is not less than 18 years of age and has obtained a permit as set forth herein. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Secs. 68-4—68-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 68-21. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Applicant means an individual registering a business authorized herein. Application means a form supplied by the county for the purpose of registering a business authorized herein. Business means the business of operating or owning a taxicab business. Certificate means certificate issued or approved by the business license director authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a taxicab business within the county. County means Coweta County, Georgia. Closely held corporation means a corporation not traded or listed on any stock exchange and which has fewer than 25 shareholders. Convicted or conviction shall include a plea of nolo contendere. Driver, operator means any person in charge of or driving or operating a taxicab, as defined herein, whether as owner, agent, employee or otherwise. Driver's permit means the permission granted by the governing body to a person to drive a taxicab within the county. Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form IRS W-2 but not a form IRS 1099. Highway means any of the public streets, alleys, lanes, boulevards, avenues, drives, circles, or roads of the county. Individual means a natural person. Interest in a business means an interest held by an owner or co-owner of a registered business; by a partner of a general or limited partnership which owns or co-owns a registered business; a stockholder of five percent or more shares in any closely held corporation which owns or co-owns a registered business; or anyone sharing in the income or corpus of any trust or estate having such an interest; or a person having subscriptions, options, and/or warranty for purchase of five percent or more of a closely held corporation's stock or 50 percent or more of any corporation's stock. Memorandum certificate means the card issued to a taxicab owner to display within the taxicab indicating that such taxicab has been issued a certificate. Non-emergency transport vehicles means a vehicle used to transport an individual for a non-urgent procedure or elective care where there is no need for immediate assistance. Owner means a person having an interest in a business, including a stockholder and to whom a certificate for operating a taxicab has been or is to be issued. Person means any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business, trust, receiver, fiduciary or other group or combination acting as a unit, body politic or political subdivision, whether public, private, or quasi-public, or any entity. Taxicab means any motor vehicle seating eight or fewer persons and the driver, operating upon any street on call or demand, accepting or soliciting passengers indiscriminately for hire between such points along such streets as may be directed by the passengers being so transported. This definition shall include non-emergency transport vehicles. Vehicles for hire means taxicab as defined herein or limousine as defined in section 68-111. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-22. - Compliance with laws, due regard for safety required. All taxicabs operating within the county shall comply with all laws of the United States of America, the state and the county regulating the speed, the operation of motor vehicles and the requirements for safety equipment and devices. All passengers, whether adult, children or infants shall use the required passenger restraint devices including child restraints as necessary. Drivers shall show due regard for the safety, comfort and convenience of passengers, for the safe and careful transportation of property and for the safety of the general public. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-23. - Identification of vehicles as taxicabs. (a) Information required. All motor vehicles operated as taxicabs in the county shall be marked on the outside with the following information with respect thereto: (1) The name of the owner of the taxicab. (2) The word "taxicab" or "taxi." (3) If a fleet of more than one taxicab is operated by one company or owner, a number shall be assigned to each vehicle, prominently displayed and identifying. (4) Any other information which may be deemed necessary to identify such vehicle as required by the business license director. (b) Affixing information. The above markings or identification shall be prominently displayed on both sides of the vehicles operated as taxicabs in letters of not less than three inches in height and must be printed so that the identification may be easily read at a distance of at least 50 feet. Such information may be displayed on vehicle with paint, by stencil, by decals or with magnetic signs. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-24. - Riding on exterior of vehicle. No person shall be permitted to ride on the fender, hood, roof or any other exterior portion of a taxicab. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Secs. 68-25—68-40. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - OPERATION OF BUSINESS
Sec. 68-41. - Certificate—Application. All persons applying for a certificate provided for in section 68-1 shall do so in writing to the business license director on the form provided by county. Such applicant shall furnish all information required by such form in complete detail and shall certify under oath to the correctness of the information. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-42. - Same—Action upon application and issuance. The business license director shall investigate the application provided for in section 68-41 and shall grant the certification if the application meets all requirements of this chapter and payment of the required fee. The business license director shall also issue a memorandum certificate for each taxicab authorized by the county. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-43. - Same—Expiration, reinstatement. All certificates shall expire on December 31 of each year, including the year of issue, but may be reinstated by the business license director for the following year, provided that there has been no revocation thereof and further provided that all license fees required to be paid have been paid. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-44. - Registration of vehicle—Required. (a) Duty of operator. Prior to placing a taxicab in service, and prior to annually renewing the permit, any operator shall register that vehicle with the business license director, providing a complete and true description of such vehicle to include the serial number, make, model and color; and a statement from an Automotive Service Excellency (ASE) certified mechanic concerning the safety of the vehicle. (b) Duty of business license director. The business license director shall maintain a file on each operator, including the description of each vehicle registered as required by this section, and he may issue identification numbers for each registered vehicle. The business license director may make inspections at any time to assure that the taxicabs in operation are registered and in full compliance with this article. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-45. - Same—Identification numbers to be affixed to vehicle. Should the business license director issue identification numbers, these numbers shall be affixed by decal or similar means in the rear window of the vehicle on the driver's side. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-46. - Insurance of vehicle; required. Every person operating a taxicab in the county or the owner of any such taxicab shall provide the business license director with a copy of the insurance certificate showing that such vehicle is properly insured in accordance with the laws of the state, and such insurance company shall be properly licensed to do business in the state and the county. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-47. - Cancellation of insurance, notice required. The county shall be given a minimum of ten days' written notice of cancellation of vehicular insurance covering the operation of taxicabs. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-48. - Suspension of unsafe vehicle from service. The business license director may suspend from operation any taxicab found to be unsafe, and any vehicle so suspended shall not be permitted to again operate until repaired and put in proper condition for use. Prior to returning to service, such taxicab shall be inspected by an ASE certified mechanic and a statement from the mechanic shall be submitted to the business license director. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-49. - Sale, trade, exchange of vehicle. (a) Notice required. If any owner or operator of a taxicab in the county shall sell, grade or exchange any taxicab being operated in the county and substitute another car therefore, it shall be the duty of the seller to notify the business license director within 24 hours of the sale, trade or exchange of the vehicle, and such owner or operator shall provide the business license director with the identification number of such vehicle under which the vehicle is identified on the insurance policy on file. (b) Transfer of insurance required. It shall be the duty of such owner or operator of the car substituted to furnish the business license director written endorsement of the insurance company issuing the vehicular insurance policy showing that the additional vehicle is properly insured under the terms of the policy. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-50. - Rates and charges—Contents of schedule, posting required. Each taxicab operator licensed in the county shall post, at a conspicuous place in his taxicabs, a schedule of rates, such schedule clearly showing distances and prices therefore. Each such operator shall furnish a similar copy of such rates so posted in his taxicabs to the business license director. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-51. - Same—Violations. It shall be unlawful for any taxicab owner or operator to fail to post or publish the rates as required in section 68-50 and, by himself or through his drivers, to charge rates in excess of those published. If the rates are not posted and/or there is an excessive charge, the board of commissioners may call for a hearing in which the owner or operator is allowed to appear and be heard and present evidence on the matter. If it is determined that this section or section 68-50 has been violated, the board may revoke or suspend such owner's or operator's license. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-52. - Maintenance of taxicabs, records by owners. Every owner of a taxicab or taxicab company shall comply with the following regulations: (1) Condition of taxicab. All taxicabs shall be maintained in a clean and safe condition at all times. (2) Record of calls. The owner or taxicab company shall keep a record of all telephone calls for taxicabs service for a minimum of 30 days for use, if needed, by the police department. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-53. - Offices below street level prohibited. Taxicab companies shall not be permitted to have their offices below street level. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Secs. 68-54—68-70. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - DRIVERS
Sec. 68-71. - Permit—Required, application fee. Before any person shall drive a taxicab upon the roads of the county, he shall first pay to the business license director a registration fee as set by the board of commissioners and shall make a written and signed application to such business license director which shall contain the following information: name, residence, telephone number, age, date of birth, height, weight, hair color, color of eyes, number of years experience driving motor vehicles, whether he has been convicted of any felonies, misdemeanors or traffic ordinance violations, and if so, giving the dates and details and any other information requested by the business license director. The applicant shall also provide the names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least two references who can answer questions related to the background investigation which will be conducted by the business license director. If the applicant desires a permit to drive for the owner of a taxicab business, the applicant shall include the name of such owner. Such permit shall be issued and renewed on an annual basis. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-72. - Same—Action upon application. (a) Issuance of permit; contents. After receipt of the application for permit provided for in section 68-71, the business license director shall consider the same, and if satisfied from such application and other evidence that applicant is a fit and proper person to safely drive a taxicab in the county, and that application complies with the provisions of this article and the traffic ordinances of the county, the permit shall be granted the applicant and signed by the business license director. The permit shall contain the name and description of the applicant and such other data as the business license director deems proper. (b) Denial of permit. The Sheriff shall investigate each applicant for a taxicab license. He shall also check the record of each applicant for felony convictions and/or traffic violations. Any person who has been convicted of, pled guilty to or forfeited bonds as being in violation of traffic offenses totaling more than 20 points, as provided by state law within the five years immediately prior to his application for a license, shall not be entitled to a permit to operate a taxicab or vehicle for hire within the county. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-73. - Same—Posting inside taxicab. The name and picture of each taxicab driver, shall be attached to the permit issued to such driver, and such permit, picture and signature shall be prominently displayed inside each taxicab such driver operates. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-74. - Same—Suspension, revocation. Each permit granted for the privilege of driving a taxicab upon the roads of the county is subject to suspension or revocation, or both, by the business license director whenever the holder of such permit violates or fails to comply with a provision of this article, whether or not there has been a trial of such driver before any court. The business license director shall notify such driver in writing of the suspension or revocation. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-75. - Same—Appeal from denial, suspension, revocation. Any person to whom the business license director has denied a permit to drive a taxicab, and any person whose permit has been suspended or revoked shall have the right to appeal to the board of commissioners, which may, by resolution, grant or deny relief as may appear proper to the board of commissioners and in accordance with the terms and intent of this article. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-76. - Same—Extent of authority of business license director. Because of the necessity of providing for the public safety and the public health, and because the driving of taxicabs upon the roads of the county is a mere privilege and not a right, a wide discretion shall be vested in the business license director in granting or refusing permits, suspending and revoking such permits and carrying out the provisions and intent of this article. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-77. - Same—Extent of authority of board of commissioners. The board of commissioners shall not be limited in the control over permits to operate taxicabs to cases appealed from the action of the business license director, nor to cases arising because of violations of the terms of this article. The board of commissioners shall have the power to suspend or revoke any permit granted for the driving of a taxicab on county roads whenever it finds that such suspension or revocation would be in the public interest. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-78. - Health generally. (a) All persons applying for permits to drive or already driving taxicabs on county roads shall be in good health and be capable of physically performing the work as a driver. (b) No person shall drive a taxicab when on account of poor eyesight not corrected by glasses, or on account of bodily or mental infirmity, or being afflicted by infectious or contagious disease or for other reasons, he is unable safely to drive a taxicab upon such roads. (c) Should the business license director have concerns about the capability of any applicant to comply with the section, the director may require that such applicant, at his own expense, undergo a physical examination by a licensed physician. Refusal of the applicant to undergo the examination shall constitute grounds for denial of the permit. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-79. - Fingerprinting. No person shall drive a taxicab upon the roads of the county until he has had his fingerprints taken by the sheriff department. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-80. - Effect of felony conviction. No person shall drive a taxicab upon the roads of the county who has been convicted or pled guilty to an offense constituting a felony; however, if such person has had his civil and political rights restored and/or been given a pardon, such felony conviction will not bar such person from receiving a permit authorizing him to drive a taxicab in the county. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-81. - Appearance. All taxicab drivers shall be neat in appearance while on duty, clean in person and dress. No person shall operate a taxicab without shoes and each driver must wear shirt, blouse or top. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-82. - Familiarity with ordinances required. No person shall drive a taxicab upon the roads of the county until he has shown, upon examination by the business license director, a familiarity with the provisions of this article, the same to be furnished by the business license director to each driver. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-83. - Obedience to law enforcement. A person driving a taxicab upon the roads of the county shall bring the vehicle to a full stop immediately upon command of a member of the sheriff department and any other law enforcement officer, and shall proceed only as lawfully directed by such officer. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-84. - Driving while under the influence of alcoholic beverages and/or narcotics. No person shall drive a taxicab upon the roads of the county while under the influence of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or who habitually uses alcoholic beverages or narcotics. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-85. - Transporting alcoholic beverages, narcotics. (a) Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a licensed taxicab service in the county or any driver operating a taxicab in the county under such license, knowingly to haul any form of open alcoholic beverages, narcotics, or other illegal substances in such taxicab. (b) Revocation of operator's license. If the driver of any taxicab in the county knowingly allows or permits alcoholic beverages or narcotics to be hauled or consumed in the taxicab operated by him, the holder or owner of the license issued by the county, under which such taxicab is being operated, shall forfeit his license and the license shall be automatically revoked. If any license is forfeited and revoked because a driver is guilty of hauling alcoholic beverages or narcotics, the licensee shall have the right of a hearing before the board of commissioners at such time and place as the board may designate. Pending such hearing before the board of commissioners, the owner or holder of such license shall not operate the taxicab service under and by virtue of any such license. (c) Forfeiture of driver's rights. It shall be unlawful for any driver guilty of knowingly hauling alcoholic beverages or narcotics in any taxicab driven by him to again drive a taxicab in the county. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-86. - Transporting for illegal purposes. No person shall drive a taxicab upon the roads of the county transporting prostitutes or soliciting or transporting persons for the purposes of illegal actions. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-87. - Cruising. No driver of a taxicab shall cruise in search of passengers at any time but shall proceed from an origin by the most convenient and direct route to the required destination. When a taxicab is empty of passengers it shall, if awaiting a radio call for another trip, remain parked at a convenient location in the general area of the last destination, or proceed directly to its headquarters or to a designated cabstand without soliciting passengers in route. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-88. - Number of passengers restricted. No person shall drive a taxicab upon the roads of the county when such vehicle contains passengers in excess of the maximum number for which the vehicle was designed. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-89. - Front seat passengers. It shall be unlawful for the driver of a taxicab to permit a person to ride with him upon the front seat of the taxicab while operating in the county, unless the rear seat of such taxicab is fully occupied by passengers; however, the driver may require a passenger to ride in the front seat if the driver feels a concern for his personal safety. The driver may also allow a physically incapacitated person to ride in the front seat. In making charges under this section, the investigating officer shall consider all circumstances including weather conditions and the health and infirmity of passengers or other valid reasons for the driver to allow passengers in the front seat. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-90. - Refusal to transport elderly passengers. No driver of a taxicab shall refuse or neglect to convey any elderly persons upon request unless such taxicab is previously engaged or is unable or forbidden to do so by provisions of county ordinances or by state law. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-91. - Receipt, discharge of passengers. Drivers of taxicabs shall not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway but shall drive to the sidewalk or curb on the right-hand side of such roadway to receive and discharge passengers. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Sec. 68-92. - Inspection of taxicab, driver. Every person applying for a permit to drive or who drives a taxicab upon the roads of the county must submit himself and the taxicab driven by him to the inspection of the business license director whenever so directed by such business license director. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Secs. 68-93—68-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LIMOUSINE CARRIERS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 68-111. - Limousines, exemption. Limousine carriers shall not be subject to the requirements set out in this chapter, other than specified below, but must comply with all requirements set out in Georgia law under O.C.G.A. § 46-7-85.1 et seq. For purposes of this chapter, "limousine" is defined as any motor vehicle that meets the manufacturer's specifications for a luxury limousine with a designed seating capacity for no more than ten passengers and with a minimum of five seats located behind the operator of the vehicle, and which does not have a door at the rear of the vehicle designed to allow passenger entry or exit: further, no vehicle shall be permitted to be operated both as a taxicab and a limousine. Limousine carriers shall be required to provide to the business license director with the limousine carrier's initial application, and with the carrier's annual renewal application thereafter, the following: (1) Proof of annual commercial insurance; and (2) Proof of state certification. (Ord. of 10-4-05) Secs. 68-112—68-120. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 70 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 18. Related laws references— Tax commissioner, art. VI; homestead exemptions, art. VII.
Sec. 70-1. - Sales and use tax. A combination city-county local sales and use tax is hereby levied. (Code 1985, § 18-2) Sec. 70-2. - Gross premiums tax on insurance. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2, there is hereby levied for the year 1984, and for each year thereafter, an annual tax upon each insurer doing insurance business within the unincorporated area of the county, in an amount equal to 2½ percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year on all insurance, other than life insurance, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(2), (3), (4) and (5). Gross direct premiums shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). (Code 1985, § 18-4) Sec. 70-3. - Hotel-motel excise tax. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51 et seq., an excise tax is to be charged within the territorial limits of a special district established herein, upon the furnishing for value to the public if any room or rooms, lodging or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by, or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the county for operating within that said special district a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. (b) The tax herein shall apply to that portion of the county that does not lie within the corporate limits of any municipal corporation incorporated pursuant to Georgia law. (c) The tax is to be levied and collected at the rate of five percent of the charge to the public for the furnishing. Of that five percent collected, the sum of two percent shall be used to promote tourism, conventions and trade shows. (d) The tax contemplated herein shall become effective on July 1, 1991. (e) The proceeds of the tax will be used in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3). (Code 1985, § 18-5; Ord. of 4-3-07) Sec. 70-4. - Power of tax assessor to refund improperly paid taxes. The chief tax assessor of the county is hereby delegated the authority, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380, to adopt rules and regulations governing the determination of whether to refund erroneously or illegally paid taxes. Further, the chief tax assessor of the county is hereby delegated the authority to approve or disapprove claims where the claim is based on an obvious clerical error. (Code 1985, § 18-6)

(Code 1985, § 11-5) Secs. 74-33—74-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - NO PARKING ZONES
Sec. 74-56. - Established. Also included is both sides of Bagley Road from the intersection of North Highway 29 and Bagley Road beginning at the intersection continuing in an easterly direction to the railroad tracks. There will be no parking along both sides of the roadway for the entire distance. (Code 1985, § 11-1; Ord. of 5-6-97; Ord. of 11-2-99; Ord. No. 005-08, 2-19-08; Ord. No. 010-08, 4-10-08; Ord. No. 038-08, 12-11-08; Ord. No. 004-10, 3-16-10; Ord. No. 026-12, 8-21-12; Ord. No. 025-13, 8-6-13; Ord. No. 036-14, 9-4-14; Ord. No. 037-14, 9-4-14; Ord. No. 044-14, 10-7-14; Ord. No. 053-14, 12-2-14; Ord. No. 002-15, 1-6-15; Ord. No. 006-15, 2-3-15; Ord. No. 009-15, 3-3-15; Ord. No. 013-16, 4-26-16; Ord. No. 022-16, 6-14-16) Sec. 74-57. - Parking restricted. (1) It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle or trailer at a county public facility, recreational facility or upon any other property owned by the county except in those areas designated by the appropriate signs as vehicle parking areas or in marked parking spaces. It shall be unlawful to leave a vehicle or trailer standing or parked in a county public facility, recreational facility, or other property owned by the county during hours when such facility or property is closed. (2) It shall be unlawful to create a traffic hazard by parking a vehicle or trailer in the right-of-way of any county public road. (3) Any vehicle or trailer parked in violation of this section may be towed from the facility, property or right-of-way at the owner's expense. (Ord. of 5-2-06) Secs. 74-58—74-85. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - MOTOR VEHICLE RACEWAYS
Sec. 74-86. - Regulations. (a) Purpose. The purpose of this section is to develop an orderly system of rules governing the operation of motor vehicle raceways within the county, and to protect the safety, health and general welfare of county citizens by preventing the creation of excessive noise and pollution. (b) Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: Motor vehicle refers to a motor vehicle which participates at motor vehicle raceways. Motor vehicle raceways means any premises used for the purpose of the operation of any motorized vehicles in competition with each other or in competition and determined by elapsed time. Noise disturbance means any sound that annoys or disturbs a reasonable person of normal sensibilities. Warm-up means the operation of a motor vehicle during practice, noncompetitive, run on the raceway track. (c) Schedule of races. Prior to the commencement of the racing season, the operator shall file a schedule of racing days with the county clerk, which schedule shall clearly state the date of racing and each and every proposed alternate rain date. (d) Days and hours of operation. (1) No motor vehicle raceway shall permit any motor vehicle to warm up or race except during the hours of 11:00 a.m. through 4:00 p.m. or 4:00 p.m. through 11:00 p.m. on a maximum of two days per week, exclusive of rescheduled events, during the months of April, May, June, July, August and September. (2) In the event of the cancellation of a scheduled event due to weather conditions, the motor vehicle raceway may reschedule the event to the proximate week upon reasonable notification to the county commission. (e) Mufflers required. All motor vehicles operating upon the motor vehicle raceway shall be equipped with a muffler as defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-8-71. (f) Loudspeakers and public address systems. No person, in connection with the operation of a motor vehicle raceway, shall use, operate or permit the operation of a loudspeaker, public address system, mobile sound vehicle or similar device so as to create a noise disturbance in areas of the county zoned and used for residential purposes. (g) Penalties for offenses. No person shall operate or allow the operation of a motor vehicle raceway or operate a motor vehicle at such raceway except in conformity with the requirements of this section. Any person convicted of violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-15. (Code 1985, § 11-4) Secs. 74-87—74-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - TRUCK ROUTES
Sec. 74-91. - Truck routes designated. By authority of the county commissioners, the following roads are designated as truck routes: (1) Weldon Road. (2) Turkey Creek Road (from the bypass to SR 16). (Ord. of 3-7-06) Secs. 74-92—74-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - RAILROAD CROSSINGS
Sec. 74-111. - Railroad crossing at Walt Sanders Road and Mt. Calvary Church Road. (a) It is unlawful for motor vehicles, buses, trucks, and tractor trucks whose length, including any part of its body or load, exceeds 30 feet to cross the existing railroad onto or off of Walt Sanders Road and Mt. Calvary Church Road from or to SR 14/U.S. Highway 29 in unincorporated Coweta County, Georgia. Motor vehicle means every vehicle that is self-propelled, excluding motorized bicycles. Tractor trucks means the non-cargo carrying power unit that operates in combination with a semitrailer or trailer. (b) Every person convicted of a violation of this article shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. (c) Jurisdiction over violations of this article shall be in the Magistrate Court of Coweta County. (d) This ariticle shall not affect the jurisdiction of or procedure in any other court which has jurisdiction over violations of county ordinances. (Ord. No. 026-16, 8-2-16)

div.head: Chapter 78 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; environment, ch. 30; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; roads and bridges, ch. 54; solid waste, ch. 62; subdivisions, ch. 66; zoning, app. A. Related laws reference— Water and sewer authority, art. IV.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 78-1. - Provisions relating to residential, commercial and industrial users incorporated by reference. The ordinance for the regulation of sewer use for residential, commercial and industrial users adopted August 1, 1995, is by this reference incorporated herein and made a part of this Code in as full and complete a manner and with like effect as though set out in full herein. Sec. 78-2. - Provisions relating to pretreatment incorporated by reference. The pretreatment ordinance adopted August 1, 1995, which sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly owned treatment works of the county is by this reference incorporated herein and made a part of this Code in as full and complete a manner and with like effect as though set out in full herein. Sec. 78-3. - Water and sewerage system standards. (a) Adopted: The development standards for design and installation of water and sewerage systems are adopted as of October 15, 1991. These standards shall apply to all nongovernmental water and sewerage systems constructed in unincorporated areas within the boundaries of the county. (b) Compliance required for building permit issuance: The county may withhold the issuance of any building permit and/or occupancy or use permit in any subdivision, development or improvement to which this section applies until there is compliance with the regulations and specifications contained in the development standards for water and sewerage systems. (c) Filing of ordinance: A copy of the ordinance, from which this section is derived, including development standards for water and sewerage systems, shall be filed with the permanent records of the minutes of the board of commissioners; and it may be inspected by any interested person during regular office hours, at the County Administration Building, Newnan, Georgia. (d) Penalty: Violation of this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-15. (Code 1985, § 19-1) Sec. 78-4. - Permit to use right-of-way. All utility companies requiring permits for use of county right-of-ways shall pay an inspection fee as determined by the board of commissioners and listed in the schedule of fees and charges for the first mile of right-of-way, or any part thereof, and an inspection fee as determined by the board of commissioners and listed in the schedule of fees and charges for each additional mile, or any portion thereof. Any permit for which the work is not completed in a three-month period shall be voided, to require an additional permit. Utility companies submitting for permits shall provide a list of contractors who will be installing facilities within the right-of-way and specifically, the contractor working by location and/or permit. A copy of the permit shall be in the possession of the contractor for that project. Utility contractors working within the county right-of-way shall provide information which meets the following requirements: (1) Provide proof of liability insurance. (2) Ability to provide traffic control and have an individual certified in traffic control available on site when required. (3) Provide the name and telephone number of the individual who is certified for erosion control inspection and installation for the project. (Code 1985, § 19-2; Ord. of 3-6-01) Sec. 78-4.1 - Specifications for utility placement (a) Underground utilities which are placed on county right-of-way adjacent to existing or proposed paved roads, which do not have curb and gutter, shall be located a minimum of three feet from the edge of pavement. Any trenches along the roadway and boring pits for the boring under the roadway shall receive proper compaction equal to the condition prior to installation. (b) Underground utilities which require traversing across county maintained roadway shall be installed at the specified depth outlined in the Coweta County Subdivision Standards and bored under the roadway. All bore pits shall be restored to an acceptable condition and revegetated. Should obstacles be encountered during the process which prohibit boring, the development and engineering and/or public works department shall be notified prior to open cutting the roadway. (Code 1985, § 19-2; Ord. of 03-06-01) Sec. 78-5. - Use of roads for water mains. As a condition to issuing permits for the use of county roads for the installation of water mains, the applicant shall: (1) Submit a written analysis of existing sewage disposal conditions in the properties to be served and the likely impact on the systems arising from the introduction of piped water. (2) Submit detailed engineering information establishing the extent to which existing sewage disposal conditions in the area will be sufficient to service future developments along the county right-of-way. (3) Submit detailed engineering plans for its collection, treatment and disposal of sewage, if the engineering information submitted by the applicant, or information developed by the county from its own sources, reflects a need for sewerage and sewage treatment and disposal in the reasonably foreseeable future. (4) Agree to terminate water service to any particular user in the county requested by the county for health and sanitation reasons. (5) Submit detailed engineering information evidencing the adequacy of the proposed water lines to provide reasonable fire protection water through fire hydrants located in or adjacent to the county right-of-way so used. (6) Submit detailed engineering information establishing the extent to which the proposed water line or lines will be sufficient to service the existing improvements and future developments along the county right-of-way. (7) Provide reasonable estimates of the foreseeable growth in development in the areas to be served. (8) Agree that it will not arbitrarily deny service to county residents requesting service. (9) Agree to charge nondiscriminatory water rates to customers. (Code 1985, § 19-3) Sec. 78-6. - Extension of water mains by developers; criteria and requirements for extension. (a) The developer must fund all improvements necessary for the water service to the specific project. This includes all project water main and service line in compliance with the water and sewer department's development standards for water and sewer system expansions. This also includes the cost necessary to run water mains on county or state roadway rights-of-way where the county does not have current water service. This cost is only the cost necessary to serve the development water service in accordance with Rules for Safe Drinking Water for the State of Georgia, and fire protection as required by development standards and minimum fire flows and pressures. (b) The water department's engineer will determine compliance with the listed requirements, and approve all plans. (c) Should the county wish to up-size water mains on county or state road rights-of-way that a development is placing to serve its specific project need, then the county will on a case-by-case basis analyze the situation to determine need, size, and compatibility with the county's overall distribution system. Then should the board of commissioners wish to up size the main, the county will bear all cost above what is necessary to serve the specific project improvement. The board of commissioners may, however, refuse to allow any line to be placed on county rights-of-way if it is their determination that it is in the best interest of the overall county water system to do so. (d) The county realizes that if it does not support the water main up-sizing and allows the line to be placed at the lower size, then the water main placed on state or county road rights-of-way cannot be used by the county for any purpose other than the conveyance of water to the specific project. (e) All cost associated with joint participation, should the board of commissioners select to participate, will be estimated by the department's engineer or designate after plans have been approved by the county and state EPD drinking water division. The actual cost will be on a unit price basis either by an individual project bidding procedure or as a change order to current water main extension contract. All joint projects will be administered by the county water and sewer department or designate. For joint projects, the developer will be required to supply a bank letter of credit or account in escrow for the estimated cost of the water main necessary to serve the specific project prior to bids or executed change orders. (Code 1985, § 19-6) Sec. 78-7. - Procedure for mitigating unusually large water bills due to customer line breaks. (a) This section establishes a policy, to be accomplished administratively by the water and sewer department, that would allow for a reduction in water rate for an unusually high bill due to customer line breaks, but not below cost to purchase or treat water and associated operational cost. (b) The water and sewer department will evaluate each circumstance on a case-by-case basis using the following guidelines: (1) A written request by the water/sewer customer stating the reason for the inflated usage, i.e. water line broken under the house. (2) Visual inspection to verify that each request is an actual qualifying circumstance by water and sewer department personnel. (3) The request must be made for situations where the monthly water usage is in excess of $100.00. (4) That a normal monthly usage is paid in due course. (c) Should the above criteria be satisfied, the water and sewer department is hereby instructed to bill all usage in excess of $100.00 at a flat rate of $1.75 per 1,000 gallons used. (d) The water and sewer department shall continue to implement the administrative policy in use for situations that qualify under the criteria set forth in this section. (Code 1985, § 19-7) Sec. 78-8. - Billing, accounting and service cutoff procedures adopted. The policies regulating cutoff rules, daily deposits/balancing procedures, and billing cycles are hereby approved. An official copy of such policies is on file in the office of the county clerk. (Code 1985, § 19-9) Sec. 78-9. - Water well regulations. (a) Prior to drilling or boring a well to be used for potable water, the owner of the property upon which the well is to be located must obtain a permit from the county health department. (b) The application for a permit shall indicate the location of the proposed well. (c) Prior to granting the permit, the health department may delineate the specific conditions of permit approval relating to location and installation of the well. (d) All water wells shall be properly protected from known contamination sources as delineated by state rules and regulations. (e) The owner of property upon which a water well is issued shall contact the department of health after completion of the well for a final inspection of the well site. (f) A fee in the amount listed in the schedule of fees and charges shall be paid to the health department for each permit to defray the costs of administration of this section. (Code 1985, § 19-10) Sec. 78-10. - Use of common or joint trenches. (a) Electric and telephone utilities may use "joint or common" trenches for the installation of service lines. Joint trenching of these utilities must be buried in the corridor allocated for electric service lines. (b) Cable TV and telephone utilities may use "joint" or "common" trenches for the installation of service lines. Joint trenching of these utilities must be buried in the corridor allocated for electric service lines. (c) All joint trench installation must be individually approved and inspected by the Coweta County Public Works Department or other departments or county employees as designed by the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 07-02-96; Ord of 11-19-96) Sec. 78-11. - Damaging, tampering or interfering with water utility services. (a) Whenever water service shall have been discontinued or cut off by the county, it shall be unlawful for any person, except an authorized agent or employee of the county, to restore the service. (b) Whoever unlawfully and intentionally injures or destroys, or permits to be injured or destroyed, any meter, water main, fire hydrants, water tanks, pumping stations, conduit or other apparatus belonging to the county and a part of its waterworks system, or unlawfully and intentionally prevents a water meter from duly registering the quantity of water supplied or in any way interferes with its proper or just registration, or, without the consent of the county, unlawfully and intentionally diverts water from any water main or pipe of the county or opens or closes or otherwise tampers with any valves or other equipment that is a part of the active water distribution system, or otherwise unlawfully and intentionally uses or causes to be use, without the consent of the county, any water pumped or distributed by it, shall be guilty of an offense. (c) Violation shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or a term in the county jail of not more that six (6) months, or both. (Ord. of 04-08-97) Sec. 78-12. - Adoption of state rules regarding outdoor water use. (a) [Adoption.] The Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division, Chapter 391-3-30 et seq., as amended, are hereby adopted in its entirety and by this reference is incorporated herein and made part of the Code in as full and complete a manner and with like effect as though set out in full herein. (b) [Enforcement.] The following enforcement policy is adopted: First offense: Written warning. Second offense: Service disconnected, $250.00 reconnection fee required. Third offense: Service disconnected, $1,000.00 reconnection fee required. Fourth offense: Service disconnected, $2,000.00 reconnection fee required. Fifth offense and any subsequent offense thereafter: Disconnected, $4,000.00 reconnection fee required. (Ord. of 7-8-04; Ord. of 7-19-05) Sec. 78-13. - Water and sewer service fees. The following rates and rate structures have been approved and are established as follows: (1) Water service rates. (a) Meter reading and billing fees.
(b) Consumption fee.
(c) Tap fees.
(2) Sewer service rates. (a) Billing fee (per metered account, for first 3,000 gallons of monthly water flow):
(b) Consumption fee (based on monthly water flow, after first 3,000 gallons):
(c) Tap fees:.
